title: Tech Stocks Had a Crazy Few Days. Another Big Week Is Ahead. — Barrons.com

children: By Angela Palumbo
The long weekend is a welcome reprieve for tech investors as they get ready for what's sure to be another busy few days.

Wall Street is coming off a volatile week of trading. As earnings results kept rolling in, investors also reacted to the U.S. losing its top credit rating from Moody's, rising treasury yields, major announcements from some of the largest tech companies, and trade updates from President Donald Trump.
The S&P 500 ended the week down 2.6% while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite dropped 2.5%.

For tech investors, the highlight came from announcements by Microsoft at its Build conference and Alphabet at its Google I/O event. Microsoft investors were mostly focused on the company highlighting its artificial intelligence agents, while Google shareholders celebrated the introduction of AI Mode into search to compete with gen-AI chatbots.

Wall Street has also been closely watching Apple stock, which dropped 7.6% this week. Shares fell 2.3% on May 21 after ChatGPT-parent OpenAI said that it was buying a start-up owned by Jony Ive, Apple's former chief design officer, for $6.4 billion. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said that the acquisition was based on the mission of figuring out how to create a family of devices that would allow people to use AI "to create all sorts of wonderful things." For Apple investors, that brings new concerns about competition, though
Apple stock then declined 3% on Friday after Trump threatened to impose a 25% tariff on iPhones sold in the U.S. unless the devices are made in the states.

The coming week will bring earnings back to the forefront. Wall Street is anticipating first-quarter financial results and commentary from AI darling Nvidia on Wednesday. Investors will want updates on how chip demand is doing in an uncertain economic environment, and they'll want to hear how trade and regulatory decisions may be impacting the company.

Personal computer companies HP Inc. and Dell Technologies will also be reporting their latest financial results on Wednesday and Thursday, respectively. Electronic products are currently exempt from the Trump administration's so-called reciprocal tariffs, but that's not expected to last.

Software company Salesforce will report earnings on Wednesday. Software results have generally been strong this latest earnings season, with executive teams providing better-than-expected outlooks, as enterprises continue to spend on AI initiatives. Salesforce investors will also be looking for updates on the M&A front, following a report on Friday that Salesforce and Informatica were back in talks regarding a possible acquisition.
Write to Angela Palumbo at angela.palumbo@dowjones.com

title: Apple has been the worst Big Tech stock lately. Here's why investors are missing the big picture.

children: By Laila Maidan
Apple's stock has sold off on tariff fears, but the company has a healthy business underpinned by a sticky ecosystem and robust array of services offerings

One thing Apple users can agree on is that it's hard to imagine trading an iPhone or a MacBook for a Samsung smartphone or a Lenovo laptop. That's probably the biggest thing Apple has going for it amid the tariff noise.

Yet Apple Inc.'s stock (AAPL) has been under pressure lately. As large technology stocks have roared back in May, Apple shares have missed out. The stock is down 8% so far this month. It's the only member of the "Magnificent Seven" that's in the red over that period, according to FactSet data. It's also the worst-performing stock of the bunch on a year-to-date basis, down 22%.
Friday's tariff-related scare added to the pain. Apple's stock closed 3% lower to clinch its eighth loss in a row.
Don't miss: Apple's stock falls as Trump makes a tariff threat on iPhones. Here's why it's misguided.

But even as President Donald Trump threatened Apple on Friday with a 25% tariff if it didn't bring its manufacturing into the U.S., analysts aren't flinching and don't think investors should either. But that point comes with a caveat that's like a pilot telling passengers they're about to experience some turbulence. That's true, too, of Apple's stock. The short-term ride might be unpleasant, but arrival is still on time. So, if you're already invested, it's probably not a good idea to get off midflight.

That said, over a three- to five-year timeframe, there's a lot of reason to be confident in the company's growth prospects because the products are part of an admirably sticky ecosystem, according to Gil Luria, the head of technology research at D.A. Davidson. His view is that the services tacked on to Apple's hardware products will keep customers coming back. It's also true that many who buy one Apple product, like an iPhone, tend to buy another, like a MacBook, Luria noted. In short, the recent stock weakness isn't a statement on the health of the business. It's more of a relationship issue between Trump and Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook.
"If you get to a point where the president is posting in such a confrontational manner, that means the negotiation isn't going well," said Luria.

It's a setback, but it's not bad enough to send Luria back to his model to rework his outlook for the company. While an additional 25% tariff would hurt the company's profitability, he believes there's still a chance that negotiations between Apple and the White House could stave off the worst. If Apple products did take an additional 25% tariff hit, that would hurt earnings in the nearer term. However, the costs could be spread out by partially raising prices and passing some costs along to parts suppliers, Luria said. Additionally, Apple wouldn't be at a disadvantage relative to its competitors as Trump noted that Samsung (KR:005930) and other makers of smartphones would also be slapped with 25% tariffs on devices made overseas as they're imported to the U.S.
Ask the Moneyist: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?

Angelo Zino, an analyst at CFRA, chuckled and called the tariff threat "noise," adding that it doesn't impact how he views Apple. "I don't think you can take too much away from these headlines," he said. Perhaps the biggest takeaway is that Cook's relationship with the president isn't as strong as it may once have been, he noted. Under the first Trump administration, Cook was able to secure a tariff exemption.

Valuationwise, Apple's stock is trading at a 12-month forward price-to-earnings ratio of about 26, below its "Magnificent Seven" peers Tesla Inc., Amazon.com Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Nvidia Corp. But Apple could see the slowest sales growth among the group, with a two-year estimated compound annual growth rate, or CAGR, of 5.1% through 2026. What that all means, said Luria, is that, despite slowed sales, investors still have a lot of confidence in the company's long-term prospects.

Apple's stock trades at a premium compared with the S&P 500 SPX, which has a forward P/E of 21.2 and a two-year estimated sales CAGR slightly above Apple's at 5.6%. Meanwhile, Apple's forward P/E is slightly below that for the S&P 500 information-technology sector, which stands at 26.8. Yet the IT sector has a two-year sales CAGR more than double Apple's, at 11.3%.

Company                                Ticker       Forward P/E  Two-year estimated sales CAGR through 2026 
   Tesla Inc.                             TSLA         141.6        10.8% 
   Amazon.com Inc.                        AMZN         30.5         9.3% 
   Microsoft Corp.                        MSFT         30.2         13.9% 
   Nvidia Corp.                           NVDA         27.7         39.7% 
   S&P 500 Information Technology Sector  XX:SP500.45  26.8         11.3% 
   Apple Inc.                             AAPL         25.9         5.1% 
   Meta Platforms Inc. Class A            META         23.7         13.5% 
   S&P 500                                SPX          21.2         5.6% 
   Alphabet Inc. Class A                  GOOG         17.3         10.7%

Ted Mortonson, managing director at Baird, says Apple's bigger problem is that Siri's integration with Apple Intelligence has fallen behand. The company is at risk of losing market share to any contender able to release life-changing generative AI services. That's something Mortonson believes could happen through Alphabet's (GOOG) (GOOGL) Pixel phones or through Google's partnership with Samsung Galaxy and the integration of generative AI into that smartphone.

That risk means he wouldn't suggest investors be overweight the stock, and he believes a stock like Alphabet is a better bet given its cheaper forward P/E at 17.3 with a two-year estimated sales CAGR double Apple's, at 10.7%.

The next important event for Apple will be its Worldwide Developers Conference, which kicks off on June 9. The company will have a chance to wow customers with any updates, particularly on Apple Intelligence. But until then, Luria believes, he said, that investors should suspend judgment about the stock.

Overall, investing is based on an individual's risk tolerance. While Apple is still seen as a solid company, and a good stock to own, there may be better risk-reward opportunities elsewhere. As for investors who already own the stock because they like the company and believe in the business's long-term prospects, panic selling based on negative headlines is never a good strategy. Instead, investors should focus on the company's key drivers. And a big one right now is how well Apple can compete in generative AI services because that will help drive hardware sales and increase demand for Apple's services segment, including cloud storage.
-Laila Maidan

title: “No chance” iPhones can be made in the US, analysts say — options Apple could explore instead to tackle tariffs

image.alt: Trump tariffs on apple, apple stock, Tim Cook, Apple india production

children: Apple is staring down a major supply chain and pricing dilemma after President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to impose a 25% tariff on all iPhones sold in the United States unless the tech giant begins manufacturing the devices domestically.
Trump’s remarks, posted on Truth Social and reiterated later to reporters at the White House, are the latest escalation in his push for US-based production by large multinationals.

“I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple that I expect their iPhones that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else,” Trump wrote, warning that otherwise “a Tariff of at least 25% must be paid by Apple.”

The president’s comments come as Apple has been ramping up production in India, seeking to diversify away from its heavy reliance on Chinese manufacturing amid rising geopolitical tensions and pandemic-era disruptions.
CEO Tim Cook recently said more iPhones sold in the US would be made in India, a shift that may now be politically fraught.
Analysts say iPhone making in the US unfeasible; say threat a negotiation tactic
Apple shares dropped almost 3% on Friday trading following Trump’s post, falling to $195.44.
The prospect of steep tariffs raised concerns across financial markets, with analysts warning of significant cost implications and logistical hurdles should Apple try to comply.
Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives estimated that manufacturing iPhones in the US could push retail prices to $3,500, a dramatic increase from today’s average $1,000.

“We see no chance that iPhone production starts to happen in the US in the near-term given the upside down cost model and Herculean-like supply chain logistics needed for such an initiative,” Ives wrote in a research note on Friday.
Morningstar analyst William Kerwin echoed those sentiments, describing domestic iPhone manufacturing as unfeasible in the medium term.

“To us, this is a negotiating tactic aimed at driving greater US investment from Apple, likely in the form of domestic chip investment and potentially production of lower-volume devices than the flagship iPhone,” he said.
Potential strategies for Apple under tariff threat
Faced with this new pressure, Apple may explore various strategies to blunt the impact of a potential tariff hike.
Morgan Stanley analyst Erik Woodring suggested that Apple could cut less profitable models from its iPhone lineup, focusing instead on higher-margin units to reduce the blow.
A “targeted iPhone mix shift could significantly minimize the tariff headwind,” Woodring wrote in a note to clients last month.
Another option floated by analysts involves stretching the product release cycle.
Bank of America analyst Wamsi Mohan said Apple could switch from an annual to a biennial launch schedule, simplifying supply chains and production timelines.
Apple may also decide to confront the administration directly, publicly tying higher prices to Trump’s trade stance.
One proposal discussed in analyst circles is for Apple to add a “tariff surcharge” to each US sales receipt, making consumers aware of how much more they’re paying because of the new tariffs.
Constraints that limit Apple’s US production
For now, most analysts agree that relocating iPhone production to the US is impractical.

Apple’s manufacturing relies heavily on China-based partner Foxconn, which employs hundreds of thousands of workers and taps into a dense web of suppliers, logistics firms, and engineers—none of which are easily replicable in the US.

“The idea of Apple producing iPhones in the US is a fairy tale that is not feasible,” Ives said, adding that even if the company decided to pursue the move, it would take five to ten years to make it a reality.
The challenges are not new.

In 2011, when President Barack Obama asked Apple co-founder Steve Jobs what it would take to make iPhones in the US, Jobs reportedly replied, “Those jobs aren’t coming back,” referring to Asia’s unmatched industrial infrastructure and labour scale.
Some of Apple’s suppliers, such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, are expanding US operations under pressure.
However, Foxconn appears unlikely to significantly boost its American footprint.
The firm scaled back a highly publicized $10 billion Wisconsin plant and has instead committed $1.49 billion to its India operations.
Likely bearing of 25% tariff on Apple’s earnings
UBS analyst David Vogt estimated that if a 25% tariff were applied to 70 million iPhones annually imported from China and India, Apple’s earnings per share could take a hit of about $0.51.
Wall Street currently expects Apple to earn $7.18 per share this fiscal year.
As pressure mounts from Washington, Apple is left navigating a volatile mix of political demands, economic realities, and consumer expectations.
Whether Trump’s threat is a hard policy shift or a negotiation tactic, it has already forced a reckoning over the limits of globalization and the fragility of tech supply chains.

title: Tim Cook's Bad Year Keeps Getting Worse — WSJ

children: By Rolfe Winkler
For Tim Cook, the hits keep coming.

On Friday, President Trump targeted Apple with new demands that the company make iPhones in the U.S., threatening 25% tariffs if the company doesn't comply. "Rise and shine Tim Cook," Trump whisperer Laura Loomer posted on X, reminding the Apple CEO he is at the center of the president's trade bull's-eye.

That is just one of the threats Cook has confronted in what has appeared to be a no good, very bad year for Apple. Aside from Trump, Cook is facing off against two U.S. judges, European and worldwide regulators, state and federal lawmakers, and even a creator of the iPhone, to say nothing of the cast of rivals outrunning Apple in artificial intelligence.

Each is a threat to Apple's hefty profit margins, long the company's trademark and the reason investors drove its valuation above $3 trillion before any other company. Shareholders are still Cook's most important constituency. The stock's 25% fall from its peak shows their concern about whether he — or anyone — can navigate the choppy 2025 waters.
What can be said for Apple is that the company is patient, and that has often paid off in the past.

This past week, a key architect of the iPhone, Jony Ive, joined OpenAI to develop a next-generation device that weans consumers off screens. After he announced a deal to sell his startup io to OpenAI for $6.5 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported that a key goal is to deliver an AI-powered device that shifts the current computing paradigm in which humans stare at black rectangles all day. Later, OpenAI told employees it is aiming to make 100 million AI "companion" devices.

It is hard to gauge the potential for a brand-new computing device from a company that has never made one. Yet the fact that it is coming from the man who led design of the iPhone and other hit Apple products means it can't be dismissed. Apple sees the threat coming: "You may not need an iPhone 10 years from now, as crazy as that sounds," an Apple executive, Eddy Cue, testified in a court case this month.

Apple isn't expected to show any AI breakthroughs at its annual developer conference in a couple of weeks. And Cook said on Apple's recent earnings call that a more personalized Siri assistant hasn't arrived yet because what the company has in the shop doesn't yet meet Apple's "high quality bar."

The company might not need to be first in AI. It didn't make the first music player, smartphone or tablet. It waited, and then conquered each market with the best. A question is whether a strategy that has been successful in devices will work for AI.

Apple makes billions in revenue from its services business, carrying gross profit margins north of 70%, compared with less than 40% for hardware. A judge wrote in a recent ruling that Apple ignored her injunction to allow app developers to bypass its steep fees on app store purchases. "Cook chose poorly" in listening to advice to ignore her, she wrote. European Union regulators want Apple to make similar changes abroad, and worldwide regulators could follow suit.

State and federal lawmakers are threatening the app store with legislation to require Apple to verify user ages. While the bottom-line impact of such a move is unclear, it could reduce teen spending or even empower parents to limit teen engagement on smartphones more fully.

Meanwhile, the judge overseeing an antitrust case against Alphabet's Google could demand that the search giant stop paying Apple some $20 billion annually to be the default search engine in Safari, revenue that is basically pure profit for Apple.
Of course, all of these issues pale next to threats to Cook's greatest creation — Apple's supply chain in China.

Trump's demands notwithstanding, there isn't much Apple can do to move iPhone production, which remains centered in China. While it is shifting final assembly of more iPhones to India, many of the components inside the device still come from across the Himalayas.
The strategy gives Apple some flexibility to arbitrage different tariffs for U.S.-bound devices assembled in the two countries.
Trump wants a made-in-America iPhone. Such a device could cost over $3,000, so he is unlikely to get one.

Cook might try to placate him by shifting production of something else to the U.S., and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent may have given Cook an out on iPhones when he said Friday that the administration wants Apple to make more of its chips here.

Apple already announced plans to facilitate production of AI servers in Texas, but Trump clearly expects more. With frequent calls to the White House and a meeting there in the past week, Cook, it seems, is negotiating his next peace offering.
Write to Rolfe Winkler at Rolfe.Winkler@wsj.com

The stock's 25% fall from its peak shows their concern about whether he — or anyone — can navigate the choppy 2025 waters.What can be said for Apple is that the company is patient, and that has often paid off in the past.This past week, a key architect of the iPhone, Jony Ive, joined OpenAI to develop a next-generation device that weans consumers off screens. After he announced a deal to sell his startup io to OpenAI for $6.5 billion, The Wall Street Journal reported that a key goal is to deliver an AI-powered device that shifts the current computing paradigm in which humans stare at black rectangles all day. Later, OpenAI told employees it is aiming to make 100 million AI "companion" devices.It is hard to gauge the potential for a brand-new computing device from a company that has never made one. Yet the fact that it is coming from the man who led design of the iPhone and other hit Apple products means it can't be dismissed. Apple sees the threat coming: "You may not need an iPhone 10 years from now, as crazy as that sounds," an Apple executive, Eddy Cue, testified in a court case this month.Apple isn't expected to show any AI breakthroughs at its annual developer conference in a couple of weeks. And Cook said on Apple's recent earnings call that a more personalized Siri assistant hasn't arrived yet because what the company has in the shop doesn't yet meet Apple's "high quality bar."The company might not need to be first in AI. It didn't make the first music player, smartphone or tablet. It waited, and then conquered each market with the best. A question is whether a strategy that has been successful in devices will work for AI.Apple makes billions in revenue from its services business, carrying gross profit margins north of 70%, compared with less than 40% for hardware. A judge wrote in a recent ruling that Apple ignored her injunction to allow app developers to bypass its steep fees on app store purchases. "Cook chose poorly" in listening to advice to ignore her, she wrote. European Union regulators want Apple to make similar changes abroad, and worldwide regulators could follow suit.State and federal lawmakers are threatening the app store with legislation to require Apple to verify user ages. While the bottom-line impact of such a move is unclear, it could reduce teen spending or even empower parents to limit teen engagement on smartphones more fully.Meanwhile, the judge overseeing an antitrust case against Alphabet's Google could demand that the search giant stop paying Apple some $20 billion annually to be the default search engine in Safari, revenue that is basically pure profit for Apple.Of course, all of these issues pale next to threats to Cook's greatest creation — Apple's supply chain in China.Trump's demands notwithstanding, there isn't much Apple can do to move iPhone production, which remains centered in China. While it is shifting final assembly of more iPhones to India, many of the components inside the device still come from across the Himalayas.The strategy gives Apple some flexibility to arbitrage different tariffs for U.S.-bound devices assembled in the two countries.Trump wants a made-in-America iPhone. Such a device could cost over $3,000, so he is unlikely to get one.Cook might try to placate him by shifting production of something else to the U.S., and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent may have given Cook an out on iPhones when he said Friday that the administration wants Apple to make more of its chips here.Apple already announced plans to facilitate production of AI servers in Texas, but Trump clearly expects more. With frequent calls to the White House and a meeting there in the past week, Cook, it seems, is negotiating his next peace offering.Write to Rolfe Winkler at Rolfe.Winkler@wsj.com

title: How to Protect Your Retirement Savings — Barron's

children: Anxiety is running high as Trump's policies upend markets. These moves can protect your portfolio and help secure your retirement. s By Elizabeth O'Brien
Retirement planning always involves peering into a crystal ball, but the outlook seems murkier than ever.

The stock market has made a head-spinning round trip, recouping the nearly 20% losses that followed President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariff announcement on April 2. But the policy uncertainty that fueled the gyrations remains, along with larger questions about America's changing role in the world and what that means for investors.

Retirement planning requires making assumptions — about how long you'll live, what kind of returns the markets will deliver, what inflation rate will prevail, how policy decisions will shape your finances. Now, the range of outcomes seems greater than at any time in at least a generation. Short-term forecasting has grown harder, too, as investors wonder if they should respond to every policy announcement and social-media post from the White House, or tune out the frantic news feeds.

For investors who are tempted to react to every new development, some restraint is in order. "This is not the time to treat your portfolio like it's a global macro hedge fund," says David Schneider, a Certified Financial Planner and founder of Schneider Wealth Strategies in New York City.

The bigger question is how to build a portfolio — whether it's for income, growth, or a mix of both. Those with decades to go in the workforce can be more aggressive — owning more stocks and other assets with higher volatility. Older adults who are retired or approaching retirement may need more stability and income.
Here are some ways to insulate yourself from volatility and create a resilient retirement portfolio.
Be Realistic About the Next Decade

Even before the Trump administration put its stamp on the global economy, investment firms had dialed back their forecasts for the coming decade. With valuations looking stretched, it seemed unlikely that the blockbuster 20%-plus stock returns of 2023 and 2024 would continue. A Morningstar roundup in January of predictions from investment firms forecast a range of 3.4% to 6.7% returns for U.S. equities over the next decade, and 3.7% to 5.3% for U.S. bonds. Those gains would be below historical stock averages, implying that investors should expect lower overall returns.

The big debate now is whether Trump has upended the math. Trump's trade war is expected to lead to lower economic growth and create inflationary pressure on goods. And there's consternation over the end of "American exceptionalism" — the notion that the U.S. is the best place to invest, resulting in higher stock prices and lower bond yields.

Worry is also creeping back into markets after the U.S. lost its last AAA credit rating following a downgrade by Moody's. Long-term Treasury yields have spiked with the 30-year bond above 5%, signaling weakening appetite for U.S. government debt.

The bull case is that Trump will strike trade deals, the economy will get a lift from Federal Reserve rate cuts, and fiscal stimulus will be coming as the GOP pushes through tax cuts and deregulation. Throw in growth drivers like artificial intelligence and a domestic manufacturing bump, and the economy could keep rolling.

Given the high degree of uncertainty about the outlook, focus on what you can control: your household balance sheet, income prospects, and building a portfolio that can carry you through retirement. A financial planner can help put it all together. Some planners charge by the hour or project, if you don't want an ongoing relationship and the 1% annual fee on a portfolio that many advisors charge.

Bear in mind: Market expectations go hand-in-hand with longevity. Many people underestimate how long they might live — and, by extension, how long their money needs to last. A man who makes it to 65 will live to age 83, on average, while a 65-year-old woman will live to nearly 86, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. There's also 46% chance that one member of a 65-year-old couple will live to 95.

We can't all be above average (this isn't Lake Wobegon), but many financial firms urge investors to add a few years to their retirement plans, arguing that medical advances and other factors will prolong longevity. Lengthening life spans warrant consideration of a 35-year planning horizon in retirement, says Michael Conrath, chief retirement strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management.
Get Your Asset Mix Right

There may be nothing more critical for your portfolio than figuring out the right mix of stocks, bonds, and other holdings. Once you have the mix, you can drill down into funds, stocks, or other investments, making tweaks to address changes in the market and your personal experience.
Advisors can help you find the right allocation. Free online tools like Vanguard's Investing Style Quiz can be useful, or consider paid tools like Morningstar Investor.

Don't ignore your psychology. You might think you're an aggressive investor — until the markets tank and your portfolio falls 30%, making you question whether it was a good idea to own so much tech. As Mike Tyson said, everyone has a plan until they get punched in the face.

Greg Dukes, senior vice president at MFA Wealth in Pittsburgh, revisits client portfolios every six months. The importance of this practice hit home during the 2008-09 global financial crisis, when the S&P 500 lost more than 50% and some clients were surprised to discover they had an aggressive asset allocation.
An aggressive mix for an investor who is still working could be 85% stocks/15% bonds and cash, or as much as 90% stocks for young people with many decades until retirement.

Investors with a high risk tolerance and a long time horizon might want to double down on tech, Dukes says. If you think that AI will continue to fuel market growth in the coming years, you could layer in an exchange-traded fund such as Vanguard Information Technology, which has big holdings in Apple, Microsoft, and Nvidia, Dukes says.
A typical moderate mix is 60% stocks/40% bonds, while a conservative mix would skew toward more fixed income, with 30% in stocks and 70% in bonds.

It's rarely appropriate for a retiree to have an aggressive allocation. One exception might be an investor who has a large portion of expenses covered by a pension, and who can stomach temporary equity losses better than someone who relies on their portfolio to pay the bills.

Retired investors could have a riskier sleeve within their larger equity portfolio. A good place to hold growth-oriented stocks is in a post-tax Roth IRA account, Dukes notes. Since taxes are paid upfront on contributions, growth is tax-free. And if the money isn't needed during the retiree's life, it's a great vehicle to pass along tax-free to heirs.
Avoid most actively managed funds and stick with index funds. Reams of research show that a very low percentage of funds beat their benchmarks over long periods, especially after taxes.

Index funds are inherently tax-efficient; since they hardly ever make changes, capital gains are minimal and your income would come from dividends. Actively managed ETFs may be less tax-efficient, but they may still be better than mutual funds that often generate capital gains, even in years when the funds lose value.

There are so many low-cost index funds that, if you're paying higher fees, there should be a good reason, says Adam Recker, senior managing director and head of equities at the Mather Group in Dallas. Don't pay 1% a year in fees for a closet index fund — one that purports to offer active management but closely tracks an index like the S&P 500. A worker contributing $10,000 a year to a 401(k) that charges 1% in fees will experience $222,000 in lost growth over 35 years compared with an account with 0% fees, according to a recent study from J. Price McNamara, an employee-benefits attorney.
Diversify and Go Abroad

Diversification offered scant rewards in recent years. All the action was in the S&P 500 and the Magnificent Seven tech stocks, which accounted for over half of the S&P 500's market-cap gain in both 2023 and 2024.

But the story is changing: International stocks are beating the U.S. this year, the Mag Seven is no longer such a superstar, and there's a strong case for branching out beyond U.S. megacap tech — including small-caps, value, international, and other areas.

A major consideration now is the dollar's slide, down 6% this year against a basket of major currencies. The dollar's loss of value has many causes. Some strategists see the greenback's slide as the start of a global shift to other markets and assets. If it continues, the case for diversification will grow, according to Goldman Sachs strategists, noting as of mid-May that European stocks are up 10% for the year, or 18% in dollar-denominated terms.

Katie Nixon, chief investment officer of Northern Trust Wealth Management, which oversees $447 billion in assets under management, says the firm now has a neutral position on U.S. equities, down from an overweight until early May. She recommends holding U.S. stocks in about the same proportion as the MSCI ACWI index, which has 64% in the U.S.

That might seem like too little U.S. exposure, but exchange-traded funds such as iShares MSCI ACWI still tilt heavily to U.S. tech, with top holdings like Nvidia, Microsoft, Apple, and Amazon.com. Adding a bit more foreign exposure to your mix is like buying insurance against American exceptionalism withering, but that still leaves plenty of room to capitalize off U.S. growth companies. "If you're an investor, you're buying companies, and our companies are remarkable," Nixon says.

Many advisors recommend that investors devote between a quarter and a third of their equity portfolio to non-U.S. stocks. Consider adding some quality factors, focusing on companies with higher profitability and lower debt levels. The iShares MSCI Intl Quality Factor, for instance, owns developed-world stocks like ASML Holding, Nestlé, Allianz, and Shell. Its 10-year annualized return of 6.6% beat the 5% annualized return of the iShares MSCI ACWI ex U.S. ETF.

Diversification can help psychologically, too — if at least some of your holdings are in the green, you're less likely to panic and sell holdings. Gold, for instance, is up nearly 25% this year. Many advisors recommend around 5% of your portfolio in gold, which could be a bulwark against dollar weakness and geopolitical turmoil. ETFs like SPDR Gold Shares offer a convenient, liquid way to invest.

While the classic 60/40 portfolio of stocks and bonds has many fans, a growing number of advisors recommend throwing in alternatives for uncorrelated returns. David McInnis, managing partner at Aristia Wealth Management in Alpharetta, Ga., suggests a 60/30/10 split, with 10% in alternatives like market-neutral and long-short funds and private credit. Some names he likes are AQR Style Premia Alternative fund and BlackRock Systemic Multi-Strategy. These are high-fee mutual funds, perhaps best suited for skittish investors; while they may be good at holding up when stocks fizzle, keep in mind their long-term returns aren't close to U.S. equities.
Cash: Stay in the Goldilocks Zone

Amid high uncertainty, it's tempting to run for cover in cash. Avoid the temptation to bail out of the markets. Cash may be a portfolio savior in a market downturn, but you'll regret holding lots of cash in a snapback. Market recoveries can happen so fast that you're sure to lose out with bad timing.

How much cash should you hold? Most advisors recommend that retirees keep at least a year's worth of portfolio withdrawals in cash — the amount you need to pull out to fund your expenses, after accounting for Social Security, pensions, and other income. This way, you aren't forced to withdraw money from a declining balance to pay the bills. Just as important, you won't have to sweat volatility if you know your near-term needs aren't subject to the vagaries of the market.

One positive for cash now: The opportunity cost of holding it has shrunk. With high-yield savings accounts and money-market funds still yielding 4%, you won't be as penalized for holding a healthy cash cushion. "You have to have enough so you can sleep at night," Schneider says. He generally keeps three-to-five years' worth of retired clients' living expenses in cash and high-quality bonds.

Alternatives to cash may generate a bit more yield and can supplement withdrawals or expenses you might have over the next five years. Investments might include short-term bond ETFs like JPMorgan Limited Duration Bond and iShares 1-5 Year Investment Grade Corporate Bond.

Also consider some inflation protection with Treasury inflation-protected securities, or TIPS. The "real," or inflation-adjusted, yield on TIPS is around 2%, and the break-even inflation rate is 2.3%, says Brian Jacobs, investment strategist at Aptus Capital Advisors in the San Francisco Bay area. If inflation runs higher than that, TIPS will return more than Treasuries with similar maturities.

A 60/40 investor could devote 10% to 15% of their fixed-income portfolio to TIPS, says Nixon. The tax treatment of TIPS can be complicated, so it's simpler to own them in tax-deferred retirement accounts. ETFs like Pimco 1-5 Year U.S. TIPS offer easier exposure. TIPS funds, unlike individual TIPS held to maturity, can lose money when rates rise. In 2022, the US TIPS index lost 11.8% as the Fed hiked rates by about four percentage points. Funds like Vanguard Short-Term Inflation-Protected Securities aim to minimize interest-rate risk.
Bolster Other Income and Social Security
While you can't control the market, you can control how much you spend and, to some extent, how long you work.

If you're able to work even a few months more, it can take some pressure off your portfolio. Not only are you not drawing down your assets, but you are padding your nest egg. If you can delay Social Security, it can boost your benefit by 8% a year between your full retirement age — 67 for everyone born in 1960 and later — and age 70.

Once retired, taking less from your portfolio in a down market can help blunt the impact of stock losses. The so-called 4% rule holds that retirees can withdraw 4% of their portfolio every year, adjusted upward for inflation, and not run out of money over a 30-year retirement. While it was tested across many different scenarios and should hold up in a bear market, one strategy for belt-tightening is to forgo the annual inflation boost in years following market losses.

When it comes to your portfolio, the best time to act is before things get choppy. "The way to make peace with uncertainty is, one, have a plan ahead of time, and two, control the things we can control," Recker says.
Write to Elizabeth O'Brien at elizabeth.obrien@barrons.com
